description: From French conniver (“to ignore and thus become complicit in wrongdoing”), or directly from its etymon Latin connīvēre, cōnīvēre, third-person plural perfect active indicative of connīveō, cōnīveō (“to close or screw up the eyes, blink, wink; to overlook, turn a blind eye, connive”) (perhaps alluding to two persons involved in a scheme together winking to each other), from con- (prefix indicating a being or bringing together of several objects) + *nīvēre (related to nictō (“to blink, wink”), from Proto-Indo-European *kneygʷʰ- (“to bend, droop”)).

verbs.description: connive (third-person singular simple present connives, present participle conniving, simple past and past participle connived)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To secretly cooperate with other people in order to commit a crime or other wrongdoing; to collude, to conspire. [from mid 17th c.]
(intransitive, botany, rare) Of parts of a plant: to be converging or in close contact; to be connivent.
(intransitive, obsolete) Often followed by at: to pretend to be ignorant of something in order to escape blame; to ignore or overlook a fault deliberately.
examples: Synonyms: (rare) dissimulate, look the other way, shut one's eyes, turn a blind eye, wink

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To open and close the eyes rapidly; to wink.
